  • Method
com.apriori.testing

Interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The interface implemented by the class under test or Object if testing a class against more than one implemented interface
    All Superinterfaces:
    InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
    Enclosing class:
    InterfaceVerifier<T>

    public static interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T>
extends InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
    A MethodConfigurator with accessors to inspect the current configuration. This is useful when configuring one method at a time, when the existing configuration is straight-forward to inspect and interpret. (Multiple methods could have varying/conflicting configuration settings).
    Author:
    Joshua Humphries (jhumphries131@gmail.com)

    • Method Detail

      • mutator

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> mutator()
        Indicates that the method is a mutator method. The test and reference implementations will be verified after the method is called using the default mutator verifier.

        Note that if this method is called after a call to InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator.mutator(ObjectVerifier), the verifier will be changed from the previously specified verifier to the default verifier.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        mutator in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        InterfaceVerifier.setDefaultMutatorVerifier(ObjectVerifier)

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Parameters:
        v - The verifier to use to make sure the mutation in the test implementation is correct

      • returnVerifier

        <R> InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> returnVerifier(ObjectVerifier<R> v,
                                                          Class<R> clazz)
        Specifies how to verify the return values after the method is called. This method takes a class token and verifies that it is compatible with the method's return type. This allows a runtime check during configuration before methods are invoked (which could cause ClassCastExceptions to be thrown later if the verifier is not compatible).

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        returnVerifier in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Type Parameters:
        R - The return type of the method
        Parameters:
        v - The verifier used to verify the method return values
        clazz - A class token for the method's return type
        Returns:
        this

      • strictExceptionVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> strictExceptionVerifier()
        Specifies that exceptions should be verified using strict checking. Exceptions thrown will be verified using ObjectVerifiers.STRICT_EXCEPTIONS.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        strictExceptionVerifier in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this

      • relaxedExceptionVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> relaxedExceptionVerifier()
        Specifies that exceptions should be verified using relaxed checking. Exceptions thrown will be verified using ObjectVerifiers.relaxedExceptions(Set), created with the method's declared (checked) exceptions and any unchecked exceptions defined (see InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator.uncheckedExceptions(Set).

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        relaxedExceptionVerifier in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this

      • exceptionVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> exceptionVerifier(ObjectVerifier<Throwable> v)
        Specifies how to verify any exceptions thrown when a method is called. If a null verifier is specified then the method will use the default exception verifier (see InterfaceVerifier.getDefaultExceptionVerifier().

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        exceptionVerifier in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        v - The verifier used to verify exceptions thrown in methods

      • uncheckedExceptions

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> uncheckedExceptions(Set<Class<? extends Throwable>> throwables)
        Indicates the set of unchecked exceptoins thrown by a method. These include RuntimeExceptions or Errors that could be thrown by a method that should be considered when verifying the exceptions thrown.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        this

      • cloneAndVerifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> cloneAndVerifyArguments()
        Indicates that arguments should be cloned prior to method execution and then verified. This is appropriate for methods that mutate the incoming arguments. In this case, the arguments are cloned (so that mutations by the test implementation don't change the parameter to be passed to the reference implementation). After the method returns, the two argument objects are verified to make sure both implementations altered the arguments in the same way.

        This method will cause default implementations to be used for both cloning and verifying argument values. If you need to specify non-default implementations then use the other methods for explicitly setting cloners and verifiers. Note that you need to define the cloners before defining the verifiers.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        cloneAndVerifyArguments in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator.cloneArguments(), InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator.verifyArguments()

      • cloneArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> cloneArguments()
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. A default implementation for cloning will be used to clone each argument.

        A single generic cloner will be used for cloning all arguments. The cloner used is Cloners.GENERIC_CLONER.

        If no verifiers are configured for the arguments then the arguments will not be verified -- only cloned prior to execution.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        cloneArguments in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this

      • cloneArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> cloneArgumentsWith(Cloner<?>... cloners)
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. The specified cloners will be used. The number of cloners provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null cloner means that argument does not need to be cloned. If an argument does not need to be cloned because it is a primitive but a non-null cloner is provided, an exception is thrown.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        cloneArgumentsWith in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        cloners - The sequence of argument cloners
        Returns:
        this

      • cloneArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> cloneArgumentsWith(List<Cloner<?>> cloners)
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. The specified cloners will be used. The number of cloners provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null cloner means that argument does not need to be cloned. If an argument does not need to be cloned because it is a primitive but a non-null cloner is provided, an exception is thrown.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        cloneArgumentsWith in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        cloners - The list of argument cloners
        Returns:
        this

      • cloneAllArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> cloneAllArgumentsWith(Cloner<?> cloner)
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. The specified cloner will be used for all arguments (except arguments that are primitive types).

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        cloneAllArgumentsWith in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        cloner - The argument cloner
        Returns:
        this

      • noCloneAndVerifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> noCloneAndVerifyArguments()
        Indicates that arguments should not be cloned prior to method execution, which implies that arguments do not need to be verified after execution.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        noCloneAndVerifyArguments in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this

      • verifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> verifyArguments()
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The default verifier, ObjectVerifiers.EQUALS, will be used to verify the arguments.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        verifyArguments in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this

      • verifyArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> verifyArgumentsWith(ObjectVerifier<?>... verifiers)
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The specified verifiers will be used. The number of verifiers provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null verifier should be passed for arguments that are not cloned. If an argument is not cloned but a non-null verifier is provided, an exception is thrown.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        verifyArgumentsWith in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        verifiers - The sequence of verifiers
        Returns:
        this

      • verifyArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> verifyArgumentsWith(List<ObjectVerifier<?>> verifiers)
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The specified verifiers will be used. The number of verifiers provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null verifier should be passed for arguments that are not cloned. If an argument is not cloned but a non-null verifier is provided, an exception is thrown.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        verifyArgumentsWith in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        verifiers - The list of verifiers
        Returns:
        this

      • verifyAllArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> verifyAllArgumentsWith(ObjectVerifier<?> verifier)
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The same verifier will be used for all cloned arguments.

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        verifyAllArgumentsWith in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Parameters:
        verifier - The argument verifier
        Returns:
        this

      • noVerifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> noVerifyArguments()
        Indicates that arguments do not need to be verified after execution. Note that arguments may still be cloned prior to execution. To prevent argument cloning, use InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator.noCloneAndVerifyArguments().

        Overridden to narrow the return type from MethodConfigurator to MethodConfiguration in order to maintain the more specific type information with method chaining.

        Specified by:
        noVerifyArguments in interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
        Returns:
        this

      • getMethods

        Set<Method> getMethods()
        Returns the set of methods configured by this object. All of the methods will have the same signature. The set will only include more than one method when the InterfaceVerifier is used to verify more than one interface for a given object under test. (In which case multiple interfaces could have methods with the same signature.)
        Returns:
        The set of methods

      • getSignature

        MethodSignature getSignature()
        Returns the method signature configured by this object.
        Returns:
        The method signature

      • getReturnType

        Class<?> getReturnType()
        Determines the appropriate return type for the method signature configured by this object. If there are multiple methods with the same signature, this will return the type of the most specific return type.
        Returns:
        The effective return type for the method signature

      • getCheckedExceptions

        Set<Class<? extends Throwable>> getCheckedExceptions()
        Determines the set of checked exceptions thrown from the method signature configured by this object. If there are multiple method with the same signature, this will be a union of all checked exceptions for all of the methods.
        Returns:
        The set of checked exceptions thrown by the method signature

      • getAllExceptions

        Set<Class<? extends Throwable>> getAllExceptions()
        Determine the set of all exceptios thrown from the method signature configured by this object. This will be the union of both checked and unchecked exceptions.
        Returns:
        The set of all exceptions thrown by the method signature
        See Also:
        getCheckedExceptions(), getUncheckedExceptions()

      • getMutatorVerifier

        ObjectVerifier<? super T> getMutatorVerifier()
        Returns the verifier for mutations or null if this is not a mutator method. If mutator() was used to indicate this is a mutator method and thus no verifier was specified, the default mutator verifier will be returned.
        Returns:
        The verifier for mutations
        See Also:
        InterfaceVerifier.getDefaultMutatorVerifier()

      • isMutator

        boolean isMutator()
        Returns true if this method is a mutator method.
        Returns:
        True if this method is a mutator method

      • getReturnVerifier

        ObjectVerifier<?> getReturnVerifier()
        Returns the verifier used to check values returned from method calls. If no verification is done (usually only for methods that return void) then this will return null .
        Returns:
        The verifier for return values

      • getExceptionVerifier

        ObjectVerifier<Throwable> getExceptionVerifier()
        Returns the verifier used to check exceptions thrown from method calls.
        Returns:
        The verifier for thrown exceptions

      • getUncheckedExceptions

        Set<Class<? extends Throwable>> getUncheckedExceptions()
        Returns the set of unchecked exceptions thrown by method calls as configured using uncheckedExceptions(java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.Throwable>...).
        Returns:
        The set of unchecked exceptions

      • getArgumentCloners

        List<Cloner<?>> getArgumentCloners()
        Returns the list of argument cloners. The size of the list will be the same as the number of arguments for the method. If an argument is not cloned, the cloner in the corresponding position in the list will be null. If no arguments are cloned then the list will contain only null values.
        Returns:
        The list of argument cloners

      • isCloningArguments

        boolean isCloningArguments()
        Returns true if any arguments are cloned prior to method execution.
        Returns:
        True if any arguments are cloned

      • getArgumentVerifiers

        List<ObjectVerifier<?>> getArgumentVerifiers()
        Returns the list of argument verifiers. The size of the list will be the same as the number of arguments for the method. If an argument is not verified, the verifier in the corresponding position in the list will be null. If no arguments are verified then the list will contain only null values.
        Returns:
        The list of argument cloners

      • isVerifyingArguments

        boolean isVerifyingArguments()
        Returns true if any arguments are verified after method execution.
        Returns:
        True if any arguments are verified
